awd_titl_txt: A Window into the Early Steps in Plastid Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The proposed work addresses the question of the way in which the photosynthetic organelle, the chloroplast, evolved. The organism used in these studies is the thecate protist Paulinella chromatophora, which contains what visually resembles a cyanobacterium within its cytoplasm, although this internal "cyanobacterium" is really an organelle called a chromatophore. Even though the chromatophore does not look like a chloroplast, it performs many of the same functions as chloroplasts, capturing sunlight to drive photosynthesis, which provides the protist host cell with energy and carbon backbones for growth. The chromatophore contains its own genome (DNA), like a chloroplast, but the size of this genome is 5-10 times more than what is found in most chloroplasts, but much less than what is found in cyanobacteria. These findings suggest that the chromatophore is an organelle derived from an endosymbiotic cyanobacterium that is in the process of evolving into a chloroplast, and as such it can reveal important information about mechanisms critical for the early events in chloroplast evolution. We recently discovered that a number of proteins important for the function of the chromatophore are synthesized outside of the chromatophore and in the cytoplasm of the host protist cell, and must be transported into the organelle where they function (e.g. PsaE, a protein that functions in photosynthesis). The major specific thrust of our studies is to identify those proteins and to develop an understanding of how they move from the cytoplasm of the host protist into the nascent chloroplast, where they assemble into large functional complexes. 

BROADER IMPACTS
In a broad sense, this work is critical to our understanding of both the processes by which cellular organelles evolved and the ways in which two organisms can come together and integrate their functions into a highly efficient single organism.  The result of this work and the concepts that grow out of those results will have broad intellectual impact in that they will: (1) shed light on early events associated with the transport of proteins into developing organelles; (2) suggest which proteins are most suited (based on their biophysical properties) to enter developing chloroplasts through systems that already exist in the host organism; (3) allow for the identification of proteins that may require more extensive tailoring before they can assume the right conformation to enter organelles (they may have to enter the chloroplast through a more specialized system that develops over evolutionary time); (4) provide a broader understanding of the development of regulatory events that have integrated the synthesis of proteins in the cytoplasm of the cell with those synthesized in the chloroplast; (5) suggest new ways in which proteins can be engineered to get them into specific subcellular compartments, which may be important for aspects of synthetic biology and the tailoring cells to make specific products such as biofuels; (6) train graduate students to perform experiments that test evolutionary concepts using molecular and biochemical tools and techniques; (7) be incorporated into an undergraduate course that is being taught at Stanford University that focuses on the functionality, evolution and regulation of photosynthetic processes ("From Photosynthesis to Biofuels").

por.por_cntn:
The work supported by this award has focused on the ways in which organelles evolve within eukaryotic organisms. In particular we have been interested in the development of an energy-generating photosynthetic organelle, designated the chromatophore, in the protist Paulinella chromatophora. This 'organelle' originated through an endosymbiotic event (engulfment) between a eukaryotic protist and a cyanobacterium.

Based on our studies and those of others, the chromatophore represents a nascent organelle in the process of maturing into a fully functional plastid with a reduced genome and the ability to maintain the exchange of metabolites and proteins with the cytoplasm of the host protist cell. In studies that predate this grant, as well as in work supported by this grant, we demonstrated that many genes originally encoded on the chromatophore (ancestral cyanobacteria) genome were transferred to the nucleus of the host organism by a process designated EGT or endosymbiotic gene transfer (similar to the situation that occurred in the evolution of higher plant chloroplasts). The proteins encoded by at least some of these EGT genes were demonstrated to be synthesized on 80S ribosomes of the cytoplasm and then trafficked from the cytoplasm of the host cell into the chromatophore, where the proteins associate with functional chromatophore complexes; in our case, we showed that specific trafficked proteins became integral to photosystem I of the photosynthetic electron transport chain. Furthermore, some evidence suggests that the trafficking of proteins into the chromatophore involves passage through the Golgi apparatus (e.g. routing of proteins into the chromatophore may occur through the secretory system).

Interestingly, some EGT genes encode proteins with functions associated with the protection of the cells from the damaging effects of high light, which would be important during the initial stages of the symbiotic association between the protist and the ancestral cyanobacterium that evolved into a chromatophore (the initial endosymbiotic event occurred 60-200 MYA). These photoprotective genes, designated hli or high light inducible genes, appear to have left the chromatophore genome, entered the nuclear genome of the host organism and then expanded, creating a gene family with more than 30 members. This expansion may further improve the ability of the organism to withstand the potential damaging impact of excess absorbed light energy (sun light). Furthermore, some of these hli genes are regulated by blue light (like in many cyanobacteria), which is indicative of genes encoding functions associated with ameliorating the impact of the absorption of excess excitation energy. These results mean that as the hli gene family expanded, some positioned themselves in the vicinity of promoters that interact with blue light modulated regulatory factors (the protist does have cryptochrome-like blue light photoreceptors).

In our most recent work we noted that many of the pathways encoded on the chromatophore genome were incomplete (the genes encoding one or two of the enzymes required for the pathway were missing). It does appear that these pathways are completed by proteins encoded by genes present in the host nuclear genome. We expected that many of these 'compensating' genes on the host genome resulted from EGT, or that the compensating gene was originally present in the genome of the protist host, and that the encoded proteins could be trafficked into the chromatophore (where they complete the pathway). While this was true in some cases, our analyses revealed that many of these compensating genes were a consequence of HGT or horizontal gene transfer (exogenous genes not present in the organism but captured from the environment). At least 229 nuclear genes in P. chromatophora were acquired via HGT from various bacteria. Many HGT-derived bacterial genes encode proteins that fill gaps in critical chromatophore pathways/processes. These results demonstrate a dominant role for HGT in compensating for chromatophore/organelle genome reduction and suggest that phagotrophy (e.g. eating other organisms and cellular debris), the major mode of nutrition used by P. chromatophora prior to the capture of the endosymbiont and during the initial stages of endosymbisis, may have allowed for extensive access to exogenous DNA in the ingested food, and high rates of HGT during the early stages of the symbiotic association.  As the endosymbiont became the dominant source of fixed carbon (through photosynthesis) for the protist, the protist lost its ability to phagocytos, at which point the rate of HGT likely declined. 

From this work it is clear that both EGT and HGT were critical for the establishment of the chromatophore within the cell and its evolution into a canonical organelle, similar to the chloroplast. The work also suggests that the initial pathway for protein transport into organelles may have involved the secretory pathway, which can be somewhat promiscuous with respect to the presequences/internal sequences required for transport. Furthermore, it is becoming clear that symbiotic associations, whether endosymbiotic or through physical surface interactions, represent dominant features critical for life on Earth.
